utterances.speaker: SHANNON SMITH, ATTORNEY FOR JENNIFER CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I will tell them tonight. I just need -- I have been in court with Mrs. Crumbley all day, so I don't know who I'm calling next.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE CHERYL MATTHEWS, OAKLAND COUNTY CIRCUIT COURT
utterances.sentences: OK.I think -- I guess it's going to be hard to believe that we're going to get past her. Maybe we will. Maybe we will. You think we will?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I don't know. It depends how long the process is. I believe I will get through her.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: All rise for the jury.All right, you may be seated. Ms. Smith, you will be calling your client, correct?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: Mrs. Crumbley, would you raise your right hand?Do you swear or affirm the testimony you're about to give is truth, so help you God?

utterances.speaker: JENNIFER CRUMBLEY, DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: All right, thank you.Would you state your name for the record? Spell your first and last name.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It's Jennifer Crumbley, J-E-N-N-I-F-E-R C-R-U-M-B-L-E-Y.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, I'm going to pull the podium up just so I can see a little bit better.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: OK, sure.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Uh-oh. I think it might have been the microphone.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: ... microphone?I think we have to move it. It seems like it became detached.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: All right, good afternoon.I just need to get -- is there any way we can put the screen on?

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: Sure. All right. (OFF-MIKE)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And what I'm going to have to do is, I'm going to leave this unplugged for a moment, so that, when I need an exhibit I will just plug it in.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Because I don't have those fancy, like, in-between slides.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: This one (OFF-MIKE)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well...

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: They don't all go on simultaneously.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: They don't. OK.Let's see it goes. I guess it's like I'm the only one who can see (OFF-MIKE)

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: This one is not on. Oh, there. (OFF-MIKE)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Let's see what happens when I just go like -- OK.I'm going to have to -- I'm going to have to pull it out each time, so I apologize in between witnesses. (OFF-MIKE) So I'm going to pull out. OK. All right, Mrs. Crumbley, can you please start by identifying yourself. Tell the jury who you are.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: My name is Jennifer Crumbley, and I'm the defendant in this case.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And how old are you?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Mrs. Crumbley, can you -- the jury has heard so much testimony. Do you agree?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.If there's -- I'm going to go a little bit faster through things. And if there's something we need to explain, or if I'm cutting you off, let me know.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK? And you understand that as I speak you have to wait for me to finish speaking?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.So, Mrs. Crumbley, very briefly, go ahead and tell the jury what you did for a living.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I was a marketing director at a real estate acquisition company.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And how long did you hold that position?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Five years.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Now, does that kind of position include any kind of presentations or public speaking, anything like that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Not a lot.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.And how do you feel right now about talking to this jury?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Public speaking is probably my biggest fear, so very nervous.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.And, at times, you have been upset during this trial; is that correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Are you OK to keep proceeding?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I want you to tell this jury just a little bit about your personality. And I think we have seen some of it on the videos. Is that fair to say?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: You have.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Now, in this case -- aside from this case, is that true in other situations of your life?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Can you give the jury like an example?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, my husband had a hard time holding down a job after his mother passed away.So, when he would lose a job, I would actually be the one finding the ones for him and sending them on Indeed or Monster and taking plans of how we're going to put certain things on payments. It's just -- I take control of things. That's just what I do.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.And you -- I want to talk to you. You mentioned your husband. How -- when did you and James Crumbley meet?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: In October of 2004.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And how long have you been together then?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It will be 18 years this September.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And are you still together and married at this time?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: We are.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Have you spoken to him recently?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How long has it been since you have spoken to him?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: A little over two years.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So, since the day of the shooting?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Or not shooting, the day you were arrested?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: You have a son?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. SMITHabout your son prior to November 30, OK?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Tell the jury how old he was at that time.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He was 15 years old.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And tell -- give the jury an idea of about what kinds of things he was into, what his hobbies included.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, he was really into bowling. He was actually really good at it. He was into metal detecting. He was into...

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What did you mean by metal detecting?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He would -- we have a metal detector. So we would go to the beach when we went to Florida out by the ocean or the neighbor's yard. They weren't there anymore, so you would go in the neighbor's yard and see if you could find old coins or cans or whatever he would find.But he liked that. He was into his BB guns and target practice. We had a half-acre of land in the village of Oxford that went straight back. So, in the backyard, we set up little targets that we got from Amazon that you can just kind of shoot down, like little whatever. Let's see. He was into his video games. He did soccer from age 3 until ninth grade. He has -- he had a lot of different interests. Coin collecting.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Do you have some interests?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK, we have heard about horses.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I like horses. I also snow ski. I'm a big reader. And I worked a lot, so I didn't have a lot of time to do the reading.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Now, when you say snow skiing, did you ever -- oh, back up. Were there any activities that you and Ethan enjoyed doing together?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.I joined the ski patrol, because the family can ski free, and also to help people out. So I got him into skiing at the age of 7. And he would come out with me on my patrol shifts and come skiing with me. So we're in that together.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What about horses? Did he ever go out to the barn with you?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He did. But he didn't really like horses. The one horse I had was kind of aggressive. So it intimidated him. It kind of turned him off from going to the barn. It's kind of boring if you're not the person with the horse. There's a lot of standing around and a lot of nothing.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.So would you spend time together with him at home?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Tell the jury what kinds of things you guys did together or as a family.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: We had a lot of board games. We also had the virtual reality set for the PS4. So we did a lot of the "Beat Saber." You can probably...(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I don't even know what you're talking about.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It's a -- it's like you're holding lightsabers. It has music and you have to, like, hit the beats, but it's all in 3-D. So it's a virtual reality headset.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. So you would do that with him?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. What else?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: We had a pool. We liked swimming together, I mean, really just normal stuff.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Did you do holiday things?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: We did.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Give us some examples.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you have an interest in, like, home improvement kind of stuff?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. Our house was an auction house.So, basically, it was wrapped in blue tarp when we bought it at auction. So we have been trying to improve the house since 2015. So we had new roof, exterior -- exterior, and then I have been working on exterior and interior ever since.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Were there things that your son was interested in outside of the video games? Was there anything academic that he was interested in?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He really liked history. He was a big history buff.We can "Trivial Pursuit," and he would get me in history every single time. But that's probably his -- that was probably only favorite subject. The rest, he could do without.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How did he do in school?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He did good if he applied himself. His problem was, he didn't try as hard as I think he could. So he was -- he had up-and- down grades. I would say he was about average.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. And when you say about average, was that something that you talked to him about? Was that something you monitored? Tell the jury about that.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.You heard about the PowerSchool app during this trial. So I had it on my phone and I was on it multiple times a day. And his grades would fluctuate based on what the assignments the teachers turned in on the PowerSchool app. Our biggest struggle with him were missing assignments. That was the one thing we battled all the time.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Why was that a hot-button issue for you?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Because there's no reason why he should have been missing assignments. He had a homeroom class and get assignments done in.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.There were -- you talked about your job. What were the average hours you worked a week?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I usually worked -- I got to the office between 7

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And we have heard lots of evidence already it was family- friendly. Were you able to go and leave and go as you needed to?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Pretty much, yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you care about your job?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I did a lot.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Explain, did you have any changes in positions over the year or year-and-a-half, two years before this?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I did.When I first started with the company, I was hired in as a social media coordinator. I stayed in that role until about 2020. I got promoted to director of marketing. And I had the position until I was terminated.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. And you were -- did you work during COVID?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I did. I worked remotely for about six months during COVID. I went back to the office in, I believe it was August of 2020.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you enjoy work?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I did. It was fun. It was -- marketing, it's exciting, and I liked doing graphic design. I did. I really liked my job.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Now, the jury already heard about Brian. Brian testified.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Tell the jury about Brian.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, I have known him since high school. We have been friends since then. You know, he's part of the horse community, has horses. And as you heard yesterday, we did have an extramarital affair.That was probably the extent of our -- but, yes -- but we were -- we were good friends too.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How often would -- in terms of the affair, how often would you spend time together with Brian during 2021?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Maybe an average of once a week.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. How long...(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How long did the affair last over?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: About six months.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Do you feel like that affair caused you to neglect Ethan or not spend time with him -- I'm sorry -- your son in any way?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Explain why -- why you don't feel that's the case.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Because, when I met with Brian, it was in the mornings. On his way home from the station, he would pass my work. And so the time I was coming to work, we'd meet at the Costco parking lot, and that was it. And he would go about his day, I would go about mine.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And is it fair to say that you lied to keep that affair going? CRUMBLEY

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And what -- I apologize if I asked this. I might have. I just am not writing notes. Did you say the when the -- the date range that that started?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It was around spring of 2021.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.And did -- as far as you knew, did you ever talk to that -- to your son about that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And did you ever talk to your husband about it?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: If anything, you lied, lied to him about what you were doing, or lied by omission, not telling him.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No. Yes. As far as he knew, I was going to work in the morning. That was...

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.Outside of those morning times, how many other times would you say you and Brian got together?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So that happened two or three times?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Two or three times.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Were there other business trips you took where he did not meet you?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, there was quite a few.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: When Kristy Gibson-Marshall testified, do you remember who she was?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Who was she?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: She was the assistant vice principal.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.And she commented she knew Ethan in elementary school -- or she knew your son in elementary school, correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And she said -- she testified, obviously, already about recognizing him. Did that surprise you?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: She also mentioned something about e-mails with you. Do you recall having e-mail exchanges with her?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: There was one regarding his report card, getting additional help in math.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Was there any time at that point or into high school that you ever had to e-mail with teachers about discipline issues?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Not discipline, no.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How often would you e-mail about missing assignments or grade- type issues?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: That was a regular -- regular thing.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. And you said you monitored PowerSchools every day. Approximately, how many times a month would you say you went to the teachers? Or was it weekly? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It would be -- I won't say it was on a regular basis, but when it happened, it was a series of messages. He'd be struggling in geometry.And so me and the teacher would message back and forth quite a bit, and then he'd start getting better and it would die off. So it was sporadic, but it was a lot when it happened.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Now, we saw pictures of your house.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How did you feel about seeing those pictures?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Horrible.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK, why's that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Because my son has a very messy room. And it was right after Thanksgiving, like right after Thanksgiving, and we hosted Thanksgiving. And it was pretty messy. It was kind of embarrassing.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Really embarrassing.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Explain the two bedroom thing or what was going on with that.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: So, Ethan -- sorry -- my son, he had one bedroom, and it got out of control.And every time I would go to clean it, I would just shut the door. I just didn't want to deal with it. So, then I told him he could just use the guest bedroom until I could get his room deep-cleaned. The day before Thanksgiving, I was deep cleaning, because we have people over every Thanksgiving. And my intention was to clean both rooms, but I caught my oven on fire in the self-clean mode. So, instead of -- I had the fire department out and everything. So, instead of getting his rooms clean, I'm just scraping out the black charcoal stuff inside the oven, so I could cook dinner the next day. But, yes, he was in a second bedroom because I just -- I didn't want to clean his room anymore. It was just -- it was enough.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you have any plans to do anything with all that stuff?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, we were going through a lot of stuff because he outgrew a lot of the clothes and the shoes. There was a lot of toy- like things that he doesn't use anymore, so we were just going to pack it up and donate it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK, and when were you planning to do that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Between Thanksgiving and Christmas, before he got new stuff.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Now, we saw a video. I guess I want to talk to you about -- there's one friend in particular who your son spent a lot of time with, correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK, we're not going to say his name, but let's just refer to him as the friend.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK?Overall, was that his -- your -- was that your son's only friend?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: That was his only friend that came over. He did have friends that he talked to during school, but that was the only one that he spent time with outside of school.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And how often would you say he came over?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, he used to walk him every day from school. The summertime, he come camp -- he'd go on camping trips with us. Sometimes, he'd spend more than a week with us. He -- I called him my second son.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK, he was the second son.Did you know he was going to be moving away at any point? CRUMBLEY:  Not that abruptly, no.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. So, when he moved away, is it fair to say it was a surprise to you and your son?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It was.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What kinds of things would the boys do together at your house?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, they would go down to the lake and go fishing. They would walk to Little Caesars or Frosty Boy. They'd go in the backyard, shoot the BBs. They'd go swimming in the pool. We took them bowling a lot.They just played video games.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Now, when you -- so when you had him over at the house -- or I guess was...

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Breaking news.We want to take you right back to Pontiac, Michigan, where the mother of Ethan Crumbley, the Oxford High School shooter, is now testifying in her defense. She's facing four counts of involuntary manslaughter. Let's listen in.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Was there ever a time where you took away your son's phone?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Do you recall when that was?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't remember exactly. I just know he got really angry about it.But we took it away a couple of times. We have taken his video games away.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Why did you do that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Missing assignments and those grades. [13

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK, so same stuff.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Same stuff.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.We're going to talk about some of the text messages. And you would agree, the prosecution admitted some text messages about one of those times when you took away his phone?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. So we will get there, OK?I want to talk about mental health. Did you ever believe that your son needed mental health treatment, therapy, counseling, anything?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No. I mean, there was a couple of times where Ethan had expressed anxiety over taking tests, anxiety about what he was going to do after high school, whether it was college, military.So he expressed those concerns to me, but not to a level where I felt he needed to go see a psychiatrist or a mental health professional right away, no.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you ever deny him or say, no, I'm not going to take you to a mental health professional? Did he ever ask you?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No. He -- one time when he was talking about what he wanted to do for the -- for his future, I don't know, he just -- he was feeling really down about it and stressed.We did -- my husband did call his school counselor to try to talk to him, because they do a lot of future academic planning with the tech school.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Was that a mental health issue?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No, it was more or less addressing what was upsetting my son at that time.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. And what was upsetting him?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: The fact that he didn't know what he wanted to do. His grades weren't that great, so he was stressed out about getting into college. He was just -- he was just having a hard time with his future goals.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Was there ever a time he was considering military?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He talked about it, yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Any other things that he talked about? CRUMBLEYto design video games. He wanted to own his own car shop, like not be the mechanic, but own the shop that mechanics worked at. But that was about it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.Were there other kinds of health treatments you did get for him? Did you take him to the doctor?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How often or for what?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: When he got sick, if it was obviously -- well, during COVID, it was different, because every little thing, I freaked out about, so we would take him to get a COVID test or take him to the doctors.But growing up, it would just be if he had a headache that persisted for quite a -- for longer than a week. But most things are not -- nothing serious.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you -- was -- did he have insurance? Did you have insurance coverage on your son?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: My husband did.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK, always or were there times where you didn't?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: All the way up through October of 2021, when my husband lost his job. And I was going to add him on to my health insurance in November of 2021 at the end of the enrollment period.That was the only time that insurance lapsed with him.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Was that one of the outstanding things going on, on the day that all of this unfolded?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It was.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Despite -- in addition to physically going to the doctor, did you have access to some kind of virtual plans?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, through my company. It's called Allied Health Network. It's a virtual doctor's visit. And, actually, the prescriptions were free too. They didn't cost anything.So we used that if he had strep throat. You can take a picture of the throat, send it to the doctor, and they can treat it from there.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Were there times that you called that -- did virtual visits regarding your son?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. SMITHanything like that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: For what kinds of things?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, usually for sports physicals, but if he had ever -- if he was younger and had a really high fever and his regular doctor couldn't get him in, we would take him to the urgent care. He's never had an injury or anything, so mainly just that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.Was there ever a time that he had an issue with a mole on his back?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, he had a mole in the middle of his back. And when I was putting sunscreen on him, I noticed it changed color. So I made an appointment for the doctor to take him in to take a look at that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Now, that was when he was much younger, correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He was about 7, I believe.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: You mentioned something about headaches for a week. You took him to the doctor. Was there a time where he had a headache issue?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, he was getting really bad headaches, that we couldn't figure out what it was.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: When was that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Started -- started young, probably around 5, 5 years old, and he kept complaining.The doctors didn't really see anything. We even got X-ray of his head to see if any -- there was any bumps or...

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object as irrelevant, when he's 5 or 6 years old.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I was -- I was just -- I didn't know when it was. I was just asking if she got him medical...(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: But it's gone on through the years.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: It -- it...(CROSSTALK)
